introduction.p: We have already encountered some examples of polynomial functions. Linear functions, f (x) = ax + b and quadratic functions f (x) = ax^2 + bx + c are special cases of polynomial functions. In general, we make the following definition.

assemblage.title: Polynomial Function
assemblage.p: A polynomial functionpolynomial function is a function which can be written in the form f (x) = a_n x^n + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + a_{n-2}x^{n-2} + \cdots + a_2x^2 + a_1x + a_0 where a_0, a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n are constants and a_n \ne 0.
The parts making up the polynomial function which are of the form a_ix^i for some i are called terms . The term a_nx^n is call the leading term .
The coefficient a_n of the highest power term is called the leading coefficientlead coefficient.
The power of x appearing in the leading term (in this case n ), is the degree of the polynomial.

introduction.p:
Some examples of polynomials are
f(x)\amp= 6x^3 - 4x^2 + x - 2, \amp g(x) \amp= 9x^5 - 2,
p(x) \amp = x^4 + x^2 + 1, \amp q(x) \amp= 2x^{10} - x^7 + 3x^6 + 5x^3 + 3x.

Each of the polynomials above is written in descending powersdescending powers, which means that the highest-degree term comes first, and the degrees of the terms decrease from largest to smallest. Sometimes it is useful to write a polynomial in ascending powersascending powers, so that the degrees of the terms increase. For example, the polynomial f(x) above would be written as
f(x) = -2 + x - 4x^2 + 6x^3
in ascending powers.
Note that f(x) has four non-zero terms, namely -2,\ x,\ -4x^2,\ \text{and}\ 6x^3. Since the term of f(x) of highest degree is 6x^{\alert{3}}, we say that f(x) has degree \alert{3}.

subsection.title: Products of Polynomials
subsection.p: Let's just jump right into an example!

In a, we multiplied a polynomial of degree 1 by a polynomial of degree 3, and the product was a polynomial of degree 4. In b, the product of three first degree polynomials is a third-degree polynomial.

assemblage.title: Degree of a Product
assemblage.p: The degree of a product of nonzero polynomials is the sum of the degrees of the factors. That is,
if P(x) has degree m and Q(x) has degree n (and both P(x) and Q(x) are nonzero), then their product P(x)Q(x) has degree n + m.

statement.p:
Let P(x) = 5x^4 - 2x^3 + 6x^2 - x + 2, and Q(x) = 3x^3 - 4x^2 + 5x + 3.
What is the degree of their product? What is the coefficient of the lead term?
Find the coefficient of the x^3-term of the product.

li.p: The degree of P is 4, and the degree of Q is 3, so the degree of their product is 4 + 3 = 7. The only degree 7 term of the product is (5x^4)(3x^3) = 15x^7, which has coefficient 15.

In the product, each term of P(x) is multiplied by each term of Q(x). We get degree 3 terms by multiplying together terms of degree 0 and 3, or 1 and 2. For these polynomials, the possible combinations are:
The sum of the third-degree terms of the product is 34x^3, with coefficient 34.

statement.p: Find the coefficient of the fourth-degree term of the product of f(x) = 2x^6 + 2x^4 - x^3 + 5x^2 + 1 and g(x) = x^5 - 3x^4 + 2x^3 + x^2 - 4x - 2.

subsection.title: Classifying Polynomials by Degree
subsection.p: The graph of a polynomial function depends first of all on its degree. We have already studied the graphs of polynomials of degrees 0, 1, and 2.

ul.li: A polynomial of degree 0 is a constant, and its graph is a horizontal line. An example of such a polynomial function is f(x) = 3 (see a).
A polynomial of degree 1 is a linear function, and its graph is a straight line. The function f(x) = 2x - 3 is an example of a polynomial of degree 1. (See b.)

image.description: horizontal line and line of nonzero slope

subsection.p: Quadratic functions, such as f(x) = -2x^2 + 6x + 8, are polynomials of degree 2. The graph of every quadratic function is a parabola, with the same basic shape as the standard parabola, y = x^2. (See .) Notice that the graph changes from increasing to decreasing or vice versa at one point. This point of a parabola is the same as its vertex (which we defined in section 10.2).

image.description: basic parabola and parabola opening down

subsection.title: Cubic Polynomials
subsection.p: Do the graphs of all cubiccubic, or third-degree, polynomials have a basic shape in common? We can graph a few examples and find out. Unlike the basic parabola, the graph of y = x^3 is always increasing. At the origin, however, it changes from concave down to concave up. A point where the graph changes concavity is called an inflection pointinflection point. You do not need to concern yourself with concavity and inflection points in this course. However, if you continue on to Calculus, this definition will appear again!

statement.p: Graph the cubic polynomial P(x) = x^3 - 4x and compare its graph with that of the basic cubic, y = x^3.

solution.p: The graph of the basic cubic is shown in a. To help us understand the graph of the polynomial P(x) = x^3 - 4x, we will evaluate the function to make a table of values. We can do this by hand or use the Table feature on the graphing calculator.

image.description: graphs of basic cubic and cubic with two turning points

solution.p: The graph of P(x) = x^3 - 4x is shown in b. While the graph of P(x) does not look exactly like the graph of y=x^3, it is similar, especially at the edges of the graphs.

subsection.p:
Despite the differences in the central portions of the two graphs, they exhibit similar long-run behavior.
For very large and very small values of x, both graphs look like the power function y = x^3.
The y-values increase from -\infty toward zero in the third quadrant, and they increase from zero toward +\infty in the first quadrant. Or we might say that the graphs start at the lower left and extend to the upper right.
All cubic polynomials display this behavior when their lead coefficients (the coefficient of the x^3 term) are positive.

ul.li: Both of the graphs in are smooth curves without any breaks or holes. This smoothness is a feature of the graphs of all polynomial functions.
The domain of any polynomial function is the entire set of real numbers.

subsection.title: Quartic Polynomials
subsection.p: Now let's compare the long-term behavior of two quarticquartic, or fourth-degree, polynomials.

statement.p: Graph the polynomials f(x) = x^4 - 10x^2 + 9 and g(x) = x^4 + 2x^3, and compare.

solution.p: For each function we make a table of values.

The graphs are shown in . All the essential features of the graphs are shown in these viewing windows. The graphs continue forever in the directions indicated, without any additional twists or turns. You can see that the graph of f has three turning points, and the graph of g has one turning point.

As in , both graphs have similar long-term behavior. The y-values decrease from -\infty toward zero as x increases from -\infty, and the y-values increase toward +\infty as x increases to +\infty. This long-term behavior is similar to that of the power function y = x^4. Its graph also starts at the upper left and extends to the upper right.

The graphs all have long-term behavior like a fourth degree power function, y = ax^4. The long-term behavior of the graphs in is the same as that of y = x^4, but the graph here has long-term behavior like y = -x^4.

subsection.p: In the exercises, you will consider more graphs to help you verify the following observations.

li.p: A polynomial of odd degree (with positive leading coefficient) has negative y-values for large negative x-values and positive y-values for large positive x-values. In general, this type of polynomial will have a graph similar to graph (a) below.

A polynomial of even degree (with positive leading coefficient) has positive y-values for both large positive and large negative x-values. In general, this type of polynomial will have a graph similar to graph (b) below.
